metadata.case_name: State of Orissa v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: The 1st respondent is carrying on the business of selling country liquor.

Excise Commissioner notified on January 8, 1971 that the exclusive privilege of selling by retail country liquor in eight specified shops in Cuttack District for April 1, 1971 to March 31, 1972 will be sold by public auction on February 15, 1971 and following days.
Auction held on notified day; 1st respondent was highest bidder for those eight shops; bids provisionally accepted by Collector subject to confirmation by Government.
Government rejected bids being of the view that inadequate price offered as result of collusion between bidders; ordered Excise Commissioner to call for tenders.

Tenders received; Government accepted tender for one shop, rejected others as inadequate price; sold seven shops by negotiating with some tenderers; price fetched substantially more than auction or tenders.
1st respondent moved High Court of Orissa under Art. 226 for direction to Government to confirm his bids and issue licences.

High Court held Government had no power to refuse to confirm bids except on good grounds; grounds relied on irrelevant; power to confirm or refuse without reason unguided and violative of Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g); monetary considerations irrelevant.
State of Orissa appealed by certificate.
Government order on January 6, 1971 under s.29(2) directing sums payable determined by auction unless otherwise directed.
Highest bidder made necessary deposits but Government did not accept bids.
Government order March 7, 1971 directing tenders due to collusive bids at auction.

legal_issues.text: Whether the power retained by Government under cl.6 of order dated January 6, 1971 to accept or reject any bid without assigning reason is arbitrary and violative of Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g).
Whether Government bound to confirm highest bids except on good grounds and whether monetary considerations relevant.
Whether after holding auction and rejecting bids, Government precluded from calling tenders or selling by negotiation.
Whether Government required to make specific order under s.29(2)(a) before selling by private negotiation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Powers under ss.22 and 29 confer absolute power on Government to grant privileges by auction, tenders or otherwise; clause 6 merely reflects statutory power; no challenge to Act provisions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, 1915 ss.22, 29

petitioner_arguments.text: Excise revenue important for State; Government guardian of finances; entitled to reject inadequate bids to protect revenue; no concluded contract till confirmation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(g) does not apply to government privileges; Cooverjee B. Bharucha

petitioner_arguments.text: After rejecting auction/tenders, Government free to adopt other methods including negotiation under wide power of s.29(2); no need for specific order for negotiation.

respondent_arguments.text: Power to accept/reject highest bid without reason under cl.6 arbitrary, unguided, violative of Arts.14 and 19(1)(g); right to trade in country liquor fundamental.
Government must have good grounds to refuse confirmation; collusion ground irrelevant; monetary considerations irrelevant.
After auction, precluded from tenders or negotiation; required specific order under s.29(2)(a) for negotiation.

court_reasoning.text: Powers under ss.22,29 absolute; cl.6 reflects statutory power, not arbitrary; cannot challenge order without challenging Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government has absolute power to grant privileges on conditions it thinks fit.

court_reasoning.text: Trade in liquor regulable; no inherent right; revenue purpose key; Government protects finances, decision on adequacy not judicially reviewable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Excise revenue important; rejection to get better price valid.

court_reasoning.text: No concluded contract till confirmation; no vested right in bidders; Government as owner can reject inadequate bids.
After rejection, auction useless; wide power under s.29 allows other methods including negotiation; no specific order needed for negotiation by Government itself.

holdings.text: Power under cl.6 not arbitrary or violative of Arts.14,19(1)(g); reflects ss.22,29.
Government not bound to confirm highest bid; can reject for inadequacy/collusion; monetary considerations relevant for revenue.
Government free to call tenders or negotiate after rejecting auction; no specific order required for negotiation.
High Court misapplied precedents; no judicial review of Government's revenue protection decision unless collateral purpose.

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishna Kumar Narula v. State of Jammu & Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: Right to trade in intoxicating drugs under Art.19(1)(g)

precedents_cited.case_name: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. Excise Commissioner, Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions on liquor trade valid; revenue purpose; no inherent right to sell liquor.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Harichand Sarda v. Mizo District Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Deals with ordinary commodity licence, not liquor privileges.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Bhimsen Walaiti Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: No concluded contract till bid acceptance; bidders can withdraw.

precedents_cited.case_name: Barium Chemicals Ltd. v. Company Law Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Misapplied by High Court; no judicial review of executive revenue decision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. S.T. Agarwal

statutes_cited.name: Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Grants absolute power to Government for exclusive privileges by auction/tenders/otherwise; revenue from payments.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation by absolute power on liquor privileges; writ under 226.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court writ petitions dismissed; Government's rejection of bids and subsequent tenders/negotiation upheld as per ss.22,29 powers.

key_quotes.text: "No sale shall be deemed to be final unless confirmed by the State Government who shall be at liberty to accept or reject any bid without assigning any reason therefore."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key clause upheld as reflecting statutory power.

key_quotes.text: The powers conferred on the State Government by s.22 and s.29 are absolute powers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on amplitude of Government power.

key_quotes.text: "There is no concluded contract till the bid is accepted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No vested right in highest bidder.

key_quotes.text: Excise revenue forms an important part of every State's revenue. The Government is the guardian of the finances of the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court
